Cards' defense melts down in second half vs. UK

Cards' defense melts down in second half vs. UK

Jonathan Lintner, jlintner@courier-journal.com 7:48 p.m. EST December 7, 2014

Video | Coach Walz talks after the Cards lose to Kentucky

Louisville's Myisha Hines-Allen pulls up and knocks down the shot agasinst UK. Dec. 7, 2014(Photo: Scott Utterback/The CJ)

CONNECT 7 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

University of Kentucky coach Matthew Mitchell considers the key to beating the University of Louisville's defense "a tough code to crack."

Yet the Cardinals let open the vault again in blowing another double-digit lead Sunday on their way to a 77-68 defeat to their rival at the KFC Yum! Center.

In rushing to a 16-point lead in the first half — just as U of L led by 14 points apiece in both 2012 and 2013 — the Cardinals blew up ball screens, played between offensive players and the basket and generally forced more jump shots than layups.

"The one common thread" in the teams' last three meetings, Mitchell said, "is that Louisville is extremely disruptive because they switch a lot of screens. So you have to be focused mentally.

Game Rewind | Cats women rally, top Cards

STORY: UK women rally to beat U of L

"… In the first half, I think the deficits have been because we don't read their defense well."

But U of L, led by freshmen forwards Myisha Hines-Allen and Mariya Moore, struggled to keep up through 40 minutes. The Cardinals were out-scored 48-26 in the second half and allowed a 14-2 UK run over three minutes to close the loss.

"It's a game you hate to lose, especially the way we had played about 30 minutes," said U of L coach Jeff Walz. "We wore down, and I think our lack of depth started to show."

U of L: Bridgewater tosses game-winning TD in OT

AND: Louisville football bowl selection announced

The Cardinals didn't do themselves any favors, either. Walz's staff calculated that his team missed 9 of 14 uncontested layups, more than one of them as U of L remained within striking distance late in the game.

"When a team is on a run like that, you have to find a way to take what's working for them, and we just couldn't," Moore said.

Hines-Allen scored a team-high 17 points, senior Bria Smith tallied 15 and Moore had 14. Homegrown senior Sara Hammond, who closed out her career against UK 0-4, rounded out the Cardinals' double-figure scorers with 11.

    Last SlideNext Slide

    Moore, the McDonald's All American from California, wasn't part of the last two U of L teams to let a lead slip away against UK. But she saw why it happened Sunday.

    "I think, naturally, when you have a nice lead, people tend to relax," Moore said. "You may not try to, but you don't feel as pressured as you do when it's a two-point game. We didn't necessarily mean to take our foot off the gas, but they came out the way we did in the first half."

    U of L, which moved to 8-1 with the loss, has a week off before hosting Old Dominion on Dec. 15.
